summary:

*Demonstrated expertise in monitoring the compliance of NABH & IOS regulations, safety regulations, and infection control measures for dental department.
*Proven record of managing the school based preventive programs.
*Proven record of managing projects-the prime minister's skill India project in Tata Main Hospital by completing the dental hygiene assistant program.
*Demonstrated ability to publish research articles.

projects.description: This clinical study was conducted to know the prevalence of oral submucous fibrosis in Jharkhand region. The project resulted in the publication of a research article: Prevalence of Oral Submucous Fibrosis and its Causative Association in Jharkhand Population TMH Clinics Vol. 6 (2) Mar, 2018
projects.title: Prevalence of Oral Submucus Fibrosis

projects.description: Under Prime Minister’s Skill India Mission: skill development program, I prepared study materials and ran successfully, the Dental Hygiene Assistant Program in Tata Main Hospital for tribal youngsters of Jharkhand from 2015 to 2017. Hon’ble Minister Mr. Rajeev Pratap Rudi distributed the completion certificates.
projects.title: Dental Hygiene Assistant Program

projects.description: This project is to help dental students preparing to pass the ADC Examination to get registration in AHPRA. It is fully functional and running successfully.
projects.title: ADC Online Preparation Course

projects.description: This project was started to determine the normal range of mouth opening of Jamshedpur population for the next project,Prevalence of oral submucous fibrosis. This project report was published as a research paper: A Study to Establish the Normal Range of Mouth Opening of Jamshedpur Population Guident; Dec’12, Vol. 6 Issue 1, 98-104 Dec 1, 2012.
projects.title: A Study to Establish the Normal Range of Mouth Opening of Jamshedpur Population

publications.description:
ABSTRACT
Context: The incidence of precancerous and cancerous lesion affecting mouth opening had been seen high in Jamshedpur. Therefore, it seemed logical to establish a base line regarding the normal range of mouth opening of the population. Aims: The aim of this study was to evaluate the normal range of mouth opening of the population of Jamshedpur. Settings and Design: Clinical in vitro study Methods and Material: A total 216 subjects from age 20 to 83 years were studied. Subjects with a history of trauma to or surgery in face, head and neck region, developmental anomaly, and psychiatric drug intake were excluded from the study. Measurements were taken twice and bigger reading was noted. Statistical analysis used: t test A mouth opening range from 25 mm to 67 mm was found Results: among the population. The average maximum mouth opening of 47.76 +/- 7.98 mm and 45.41 +/- 9.76 mm were found for males and females respectively. The maximum mouth opening for the population was 46.82 +/- 8.8 mm. It was found that 41.2 % of the population fell in the MMO range of 41-50 mm; 28.24 % in 51-60 mm; and 18.98 % in 31-40 mm. Thus a total of 70 % of Jamshedpur population fell within a mouth opening range of 41-60 mm. Conclusions: A baseline data regarding the normal range of mouth opening of the Jamshedpur population was established. These indings can be used to arrive at a diagnosis in different disease conditions of restricted mouth opening.
publications.name: A STUDY TO ESTABLISH THE NORMAL RANGE OF MOUTH OPENING OF JAMSHEDPUR POPULATION
Oral Tissue Trauma in an Adult Male by a Tooth Brush:A Case Report and Review of literature
publications.description: The intraoral trauma by a tooth brush in an adult is a very rare occurrence, although it occurs frequently in children. This report describes an extremely rare case of accidental intra-oral intrusion of a tooth brush, buccal to the left mandibular second molar, in the left lower vestibule of an adult, and its surgical management under general anesthesia.It also analyses the different types of trauma caused by tooth brushes in different locations in oral cavity and their management based on the published literature that are available on the net.

publications.description: Objectives: 1. To familiarise the prosthodontists with nanodentistry. 2. To familiarise the audience with recent advances in nanodentistry. 3. To enlighten the prosthodontists about application of nanodentistry in prosthodontics.. . Materials and methods: the scientific published research materials were screened and suitable literature materials were included for presentation.. . Results: after attending this presentation, the audience will be familiar with recent advancements in nanodentistry.. . Conclusion: the returning prosthodontists will be better able to perform well clinically as well as academically while dealing with nanomaterials.
publications.name: Nanodentistry: Recent Advances and their applications in Prosthodontics JIPS Vol. 18 Issue 6, P76, 2018

ingestedContentSummary.description: The ‘custom trays’ also known as ‘special trays’ are fabricated so that the final impression of the patient’s edentulous mouth can be made accurately using selective pressure technique with proper border extensions. The selective pressure technique helps in making the impression in such a way that when the newly fabricated dentures are in function in the mouth of the patient, they exert pressure…
ingestedContentSummary.title: Stress Bearing Areas and Special Trays: Detailed Dental Insights

message.text: Putting masticatory load over the load bearing area of the residual alveolar ridge, sparing the non load bearing area, is extremely important for a successful denture. Yow ill learn as to how to do it in this article by the use of special trays.
